text: so when whenever we have a memory uh
about some experience turns out that
there are probably a lot of different
systems in the brain that are being
activated you know we sometimes as
scientists we sometimes talk about
memory systems but I sort of think that
that's a a misnomer because if you think
about what memory is it's um it's
really plasticity in the nervous system
it's the ability of neurons in the brain
to change and neurons in every part of
the brain that have ever been looked at
have this capability of changing of
becoming plastic when their uh
experiences changed now from the point
of view of a neuron an experience is the
arrival of neurotransmitter being
released by another neuron so um what
that does is it changes the way that
neuron responds and across many such
events like that in the brain uh a
memory is formed or multiple memories
are formed so it's really inappropriate
to talk about memory systems because
almost every system in the brain forms
memories so what we like to think about
instead or the way I like to think about
it is that memory is a feature of
neurons rather than a function of brain
systems
so as information goes through a brain
system uh if that information is
significant it will form a lasting Trace
as a result of the release of the
transmitter and the other um things that
are going on at that same time will form
a trace a connection between the active
neurons and that will stay in the brain
in the form of what we then experience
as memory later now let's take a
situation where you're driving down the
road um and you have an accident you hit
your head on the steering wheel and you
hit it really hard and the horn gets
stuck on and so you hear this loud
annoying noise uh while you're bleeding
in pain it's really awful and terrible
and then a few days later you hear the
sound of a horn
so that sound will go to various parts
of your brain simultaneously when it
goes to a part of the brain called the
hippocampus it will remind you of the um
the situation that you were in that you
were driving you had an accident that
you were with John and and Peg um but
you won't know it won't have the
emotional impact unless it also goes to
a different part of the brain called the
amydala which instead of reminding you
of the details of the event will trigger
emotional responses in your brain and
body and the ones in the body will feed
back to the brain and all of that
activity in the brain uh will give rise
to what we call the emotion so back to
the the fear example the sound of the
horn goes to one part of the brain the
amydala and gives rise to the emotional
response and to the other part of the
brain the hippocampus and gives rise to
the cognitive representation so we call
the hippocampal memory a memory about
the emotion whereas the amydala memory
we call me the emotional memory itself
now these two things happen
simultaneously the amydala memory is
triggered
unconsciously uh you don't have to be
aware of the stimulus in order for that
to be triggered hippocampal memory uh is
probably triggered unconsciously as well
but you become aware of the memory when
it's triggered because of the uh what
that's what a hipocampal memory does is
it creates a representation in conscious
experience but that conscious
representation now is going to be
Amplified by the emotional arousal that
taking place is going to create a new
emotional memory uh or a new memory
about emotion that's going to have that
kind of emotional stamp on it so it's
the interaction between cognitive
systems and emotion systems in the brain
uh that create what's called sometimes
flashball memories which are very Vivid
strong memories of a particular
experience everyone my age remembers the
assassination of of John Kennedy in the
60s we remember where we were what we
were doing and all those gory details
now it used to be thought that these
flash bulb meor memories were more
accurate than other memories but new
research by Liz Phelps my colleague at
NYU and and other researchers who study
humans have shown that these flashball
memories are not more accurate they're
just more Vivid so the accuracy is is
kind of um suspect and one of the
consequences or one of the implications
of that is that memories are constructed
or reconstructed when they're retrieved
and at that point of retrieval the
memory has the opportunity to be changed
and that's one of the main topics we've
been working on lately is how memory is
changed uh when it's
retrieved so a good example of the um
the change the way memory changes uh
during the retrieval process is um a
situation where someone goes to court to
testify about a crime that they
witnessed and on the day of the crime
they you know gave they gave their um uh
summary of what happened to the police
so there's a police record at the time
and then when they go into the court
they talk about something completely
different which it turns out happens to
match what they read about in the
newspaper um and so when they read the
newspaper what they did was they updated
their memory about the experience and
then in the future when you retrieve
that memory it's hard to distinguish you
know what actually happened and what
you've Incorporated since in uh through
other kinds of experiences
and this is now a well-known phenomenon
that um each time a memory is taken out
the opportunity is there for it to be
changed and normally this is an updating
process and it's a useful thing um you
meet somebody at a party and uh you say
that's a nice guy but then you find out
he's an ax murder or something like that
you have to you know immediately change
your memory of that person so you've
updated it um but in the in the case
there are other ways that memory gets
updated as well which is that um
let's go back to the example of fear
conditioning in the rats so we condition
a rat to be afraid of the tone so the
next day he hears the tone and he
freezes because that's how rats Express
Their Fear of a stimulus um but if
immediately after presenting that tone
we give the rat um a certain kind of
drug which I'll explain later uh and we
test the rat the next day the memory is
no longer present or at least can't be
accessed so what's going on well it's
been known for a long time that memory
formation or memory
consolidation uh requires the synthesis
of new proteins in the parts of the
brain that are forming the memory so um
other researchers discovered then that
memory um that if you block protein
synthesis after retrieval you can also
disrupt the stability of the memory
later but that idea kind of got lost in
the late 60s and didn't stick around
what stuck around was the idea that
memories are Consolidated and once
they're Consolidated each time you take
it out you take out that same Trace over
and over again so the the new research
which uh my lab helped sort of
rejuvenate in the year
um was
about manipulating the memory after the
r experiences the retrieval process so
we give the WRA the tone and then we
block protein synthesis after retrieval
rather than after learning and when we
do that again the memory is uh
eliminated just as well after retrieval
as it is uh as it's prevented from AC
being acquired after learning if you
block protein synthesis so um the unique
feature of our experiment was we were
able to do this in the side of the brain
where the memory is being formed and
stored which in the case of fear
conditioning memory is the uh the
amydala so because we had done all the
the basic work of figuring out those
circuits we could go in and put a tiny
amount of a protein synthesis inhibitor
in the amydala and that's important
because you can also do this experiment
by giving the protein synthes synthesis
inhibitor systemically to the whole body
like if you if you take a pill that goes
into your body and reaches your brain
and does uh all the stuff but it's going
everywhere and that's why many drugs
have side effects so if you take uh an
anti-anxiety drug it not only um
relieves anxiety but it make you sleepy
might alter your sex drive blah blah
blah so um what we're doing here is
avoiding one of the bad consequences of
protein synthesis Inhibitors which is it
makes you nauseous and sick and so forth
if you take it
systemically uh and it it is pretty
toxic so you would never give a drug
like that to a human uh this is only
something you can do in an animal
experiment um so the um protein
synthesis inhibitor in our studies I was
put directly in the amydala and we avoid
all those side effects and negative
consequences since it's a tiny amount it
doesn't affect the rest of the body so
when we do that the the the rats the
next day don't freeze to the tone they
don't remember that the tone is now
dangerous so this has triggered a whole
wave of research now on the possibility
of using this as a treatment for
post-traumatic stress disorder because
you know theoretically we can have the
people come in remember their trauma
give them a pill and the next time the
the cues about the trauma come along
they won't have the emotional response
to it
well when I was a kid I was really
afraid of snakes I grew up in Louisiana
where there are tons of really awful
snakes called water moccasins um and we
used to go water skiing all the time and
every water skiing spot has this legend
of the person who falls in the water and
says oh I'm trapped in some barbed wire
or something down here and they pull him
out and he's covered with little tons of
baby water moccasins just sucking away
on uh on him um so I I was a really good
water skier cuz I learned to ski without
getting wet so I would stand up stand on
the um Pier and the boat would take off
and just jump in on the skis and ski
around and then just ski back up on the
land so uh but I the way I acquired the
sphar of snakes I think is um we went
crawfishing once at this old Bayou and
um there were it was a hot afternoon and
the Bayou had a I remember this very
vividly this is my flashball memory who
knows if it's accurate but it's very
Vivid so it has the sloping um uh side
of the uh Bank of the the Bayou and
there were like it seems thousands of
snakes on both sides just kind of
Basking in the Sun and I just formed a
really terrifying vivid memory but I you
know I don't really worry about snakes
anymore I I when I was younger I would
if I turned a picture of a snake in a
magazine it you know freak me out but it
doesn't really bother me anymore
